articles.author: Vigneshwaralingam
articles.description:
1. CSS ID vs Class What? ID is a unique identifier for an HTML element. Class is a reusable identifier that can be assigned to multiple elements. Use ID when you want to style or manipulate one unique element on the page. Use Class when you want to style or select multiple elements with the same styles. IDs have higher specificity, so they override classes if both are applied to the same element. Classes promote reusable styles and avoid duplication. Feature ID Class Uniqueness Unique per page Can be used on multiple elements Selector syntax #idName .className Specificity Higher Lower Usage Single element styling Group of elements
Header
Box 1
Box 2
#header { background-color: blue; col‚Ä¶
articles.title: CSS Blog: ID vs Class, Main Axis vs Cross Axis, Flexbox Properties, Justify Content vs Text Align Center ‚ÄîInterview Q&A

articles.author: Vigneshwaralingam
articles.description:
What is a CSS Media Query?


A CSS Media Query is a technique used in CSS to apply styles conditionally based on the characteristics of the device or viewport displaying the content. It allows you to create responsive designs that adapt to different screen sizes, resolutions, orientations, and more.
When you want your website or app to look good on all devices (mobile, tablet, desktop).
When you want to change layouts, font sizes, or hide/show elements depending on screen size.
When you want to optimize performance by loading or styling content specifically for device capabilities.
When you want to implement responsive web design (RWD).
To improve user experience on different devices.
To ensure your site is accessible and readable on small screens.
To avoid horizontal scrolling on mobile d‚Ä¶
articles.title: CSS Media Queries: When, What, Why, Which, How, Differences, and Examples

articles.author: Vigneshwaralingam
articles.description:
‚ùì What is Flexbox?


Flexbox (Flexible Box Layout) is a one-dimensional layout system in CSS used to align and distribute space among items inside a container. It works in either a row or a column, but not both at the same time.
Use Flexbox when:
You want to align elements horizontally or vertically

You want to space items evenly

You need to build responsive layouts

You want easy alignment without using floats or position







  
  
  üí° Why is Flexbox Important?



It simplifies layout design

Handles resizing and spacing automatically

Replaces old hacks like float, inline-block, and positioning

Great for navbars, cards, buttons, galleries, footers, and more
display: flex;
flex-direction
justify-content
align-items
flex-wrap
gap
flex
align-self
order
flex-grow, flex-shrink, flex-ba‚Ä¶
articles.title: üí™ CSS Flexbox ‚Äî What, When, Why, Which, How, Differences, Examples, and Interview Q\&A

articles.author: Vigneshwaralingam
articles.description:
‚ùì What is position in CSS?


The position property in CSS defines how an element is placed in the document layout. It controls whether an element follows the normal flow or is manually positioned using top, left, right, and bottom.
position?


Use it when you want to:
Fix something on screen (like a navbar or button)
Layer items (like overlays, modals, tooltips)
Place elements relative to a parent or the page
position important?



Helps create dynamic, interactive UIs
Essential for responsive layout behavior
Works with z-index, top, left, etc. for fine control
Used in modals, tooltips, sticky headers, buttons, etc.
You can apply it to any block, inline, or inline-block element:
.box {
  position: relative;
  top: 20px;
}




Value
Description




static
Default value. Element follows norm‚Ä¶
articles.title: üìå CSS `position` Property ‚Äì What, When, Why, Where, Which, How + Examples & Interview Q&A

articles.author: Sameer Chawla
articles.description:
üß† LeetCode #56 (Merge Intervals) ‚Äî Needed a Few Tries to Crack It
It took me over 2 hours and 3 failed attempts to solve [LeetCode 56: Merge Intervals].
Why?

Because sometimes the problem description and examples just aren‚Äôt enough to guide you ‚Äî and that‚Äôs part of the challenge.
Some tricky cases like:

[[1,4],[2,3]]

[[1,4],[0,4]]

kept failing.

I assumed the intervals were always in sorted order ‚Äî they weren‚Äôt.
Then I peeked at the solution and saw:

sort(intervals.begin(), intervals.end());

That one line changed everything.
I paused, dug into how 2D sorting works in C++, and that helped unlock the logic.
‚úÖ How sorting works for 2D vectors

üó£Ô∏è Reading discussions and others‚Äô code can speed up learning

‚úçÔ∏è Writing it by hand helped reinforce the logic  
üì∏ Sharing my handwritten notes and final accepted solution in C++:





If you're just starting out too ‚Äî remember: it's okay to take time. The goal is to learn.





  
  
  üè∑ Hashtags



  
  
  LearnInPublic #Cplusplus #LeetCode #ProblemSolving #BeginnerDev #CodingJourney #DeveloperJourney #DSA #Cpp #Debugging #LeetCodeSolutions #ProblemSolvingSkills
articles.title: üß† LeetCode #56 (Merge Intervals) ‚Äî Needed a Few Tries to Crack It

articles.author: Todd Bernson
articles.description:
By Todd Bernson, CTO of BSC Analytics, Voice Architect, and Guy Who Politely Declined Polly‚Äôs Help Because He Could Do It Better Himself
Let‚Äôs get something straight: Amazon Polly is great ‚Äî until it isn‚Äôt. If you‚Äôre building a chatbot, narrating product updates, or making your app sound vaguely robotic (in a ‚Äúpleasant call center‚Äù way), Polly delivers. It‚Äôs fast, it‚Äôs affordable, and it supports multiple languages with all the predictable cheer of a Disney ride operator.
But what happens when you want your voice app to sound... like you? Or your CEO? Or your 90-year-old grandfather? What if you need complete control over pronunciation, tone, pause patterns, and the ability to train on custom audio that would make Polly blush?
This is where the polite fa√ßade of managed services starts to f‚Ä¶
articles.title: Beyond Polly: Custom Voice Cloning on AWS vs. Using Native AWS AI Services

articles.author: Vigneshwaralingam
articles.description:
The display property in CSS is like the foundation of how elements behave on your web page. Whether you're placing a button, text, navbar, or card ‚Äî the display property decides how it will appear and interact.
Let‚Äôs break it down using the 5W1H method for easy learning and interview prep.
display property?


The display property defines how an HTML element should behave in the layout ‚Äî as a block, inline, grid, flex, etc. It controls whether elements stack, sit side-by-side, take full width, or just wrap their content.
display?


Use it whenever you want to:
Control layout behavior (horizontal/vertical)
Change how elements appear (e.g., from block to inline)
Build responsive UIs (with flex or grid)
Hide/show elements (display: none)
display important?



It determines spacing, alignment, ‚Ä¶
articles.title: üß± CSS `display` Property ‚Äî What, When, Why, Where, How, and Which

articles.author: David Madrid
articles.description:
Building dynamic sidebars is far from trivial. A maintainable and scalable solution requires a modern, well-structured approach ‚Äî especially when dealing with multiple user roles and navigation scenarios. Without solid architecture, hardcoded components quickly become unmanageable as your application grows.
Instead of relying on hardcoded items, you can define a sidebar configuration as data and render items dynamically based on user roles. Here‚Äôs a clean and extensible approach using TypeScript:
type SidebarItem = {
  id: string
  title: string
  icon: keyof typeof Icons
  to: string
  allowedRoles: UserRole[]
  activeUrls?: string[]
}

const sidebarItems: SidebarItem[] = [
  {
    id: "dashboard",
    title: t("labels.dashboard"),
    icon: "dashboard",
    to: "/dashboard",
    allowedR‚Ä¶
articles.title: Role-Based Sidebar Navigation in React Applications

articles.author: Dev Cookies
articles.description:
In modern microservices architectures, services often need to communicate both ways ‚Äî sending and receiving messages asynchronously. While REST-based synchronous APIs are easy to start with, they don't scale well under high loads or when services are temporarily unavailable.
This is where Apache Kafka shines ‚Äî providing durable, fault-tolerant, and decoupled communication through an event-driven model.
In this blog, we‚Äôll build a bidirectional communication flow between two Spring Boot microservices using Spring Cloud Stream and Kafka.



Feature
Benefit




üßµ Asynchronous
Non-blocking communication


üîÅ Resilient
Retry, Dead-letter topics


üîå Decoupled
Producers don‚Äôt need to know who consumes the message


üîÑ Bidirectional
Services can act as both consumer and producer


üì¶ Spring Clou‚Ä¶
articles.title: üîÅ Bidirectional Service-to-Service Communication using Kafka in Spring Boot with Spring Cloud Stream

articles.author: Crosston J
articles.description:
Hello , Everyone 
I'm from Tamil Nadu and I recently completed my bachelor's in computer application .life hasn't been easy - I've faced deep emotional battles, family responsibilities and moments where everything felt too heavy to carry.
But even when i broke , I never stayed broken .I kept learning , kept dreaming & kept choosing growing .
Why I'm Here
I joined dev.to to document my journey - not just as a tech learner , but as a human being rebuilding from the ground up . I believe in sharing raw , honest learning , not just polished perfection.
You‚Äôll see posts from me like:
What I learned in my classes today
Simple Java logic I tried and failed at (and then succeeded!)
How coding is helping me heal and move forward
My Dream
One day, I want to build something meaningful ‚Äî something that helps people feel seen and supported, especially those who feel left out. Tech is not just my career goal; it's my way of creating a life with purpose.
** To Anyone Reading This: **
If you‚Äôre also starting, or restarting, or just tired ‚Äî I want to say this:

You don‚Äôt need to be perfect to begin.

You just need to begin. 
Thanks for reading my first post. I‚Äôll be back tomorrow ‚Äî not to impress, but to express.
By
Jackcup Crosston
articles.title: Who I'm - a Developer With a dream ( And a heavy heart that Never Gave up )
